title: What makes a product launch successful? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Consider the following strategies for launching a new product to market: 1. Study your competition Before launching your product to market, you need to take a serious look at your competitors. Create an excel sheet and make a list of businesses or companies that offer a similar product that you are planning to launch. After knowing your competitors, review their marketing strategies, including their ads, websites, etc. The bottom line is that your product should be unique and meets the needs of your best prospects. 2. Target the ideal customer To successfully launch your new product, it is essential to focus on the prospects that you believe are most likely to purchase from you. These can be the same customers who are currently buying the same product from the market and are looking for new features that your product or service might be providing. 3. Create a unique value proposition Now at this stage, you need to have a clear understanding of what you need to offer and who will take advantage of what you offer. Customers will buy your product because of the benefits and features that you will provide that your customers will value most. 4. Define your marketing strategy and tactics Now, you need to choose your sales and marketing channels to sell your product. If you want to sell your product online on your website then you can follow below strategies to drive more traffic to your website and generate more sales: Social Media Share your idea on Facebook, Reddit, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, Stumbleupon, and Forums, etc.Create a Facebook group and add related people to it.Join relevant Facebook groups and talk about your projectInvest in Facebook AdsGo on relevant subreddits on Reddit and talk about your projectEmail Marketing Use traditional Email Marketing Launch to reveal your product.Send Email to individuals and let them know about your product.Google Adwords Google Adwords is great, but also a little expensive and time-consuming.Landing Page Build a landing page that promises something appealing to get people to sign up, such as early bird discounts etc.You can use social media to drive traffic to your landing page.The goal of the landing page will be to get people to sign up and create your email list.Try MizoAI landing page software tool for creating high conversion landing pages5. Test your concept and marketing approach It is best to inspect your product and your marketing strategies before proceeding to the final creation of your marketing tools and materials. 6. Roll out your campaign This is how Blocks the modular smartwatch raised over $1.66 million and launched its hardware product. My first project I got involved in was a smartwatch called BLOCKS, the world’s first modular smartwatch. Blocks was a smartwatch you could put together like Lego. Each module of the BLOCKS watch has a specific function – a heart rate monitor, contactless payment card, GPS, and more. We launched our BLOCKS Kickstarter campaign on October the 13th, and by the end of the campaign, we raised $1,613,874. We reached our initial goal of $250,000 in just 56 minutes. You don’t have to have the perfect product to succeed, but it must be exciting. There are 7 billion people on this planet. If it excites you, it will excite others, no matter how niche it is. I’ve got a number of great resources on my website: samitpatel. net 7. Know your product’s life cycle You need to regularly update the campaign that you used to introduce or launch your product as your product or service matures. Monitor your marketing results carefully as that will indicate you when it is time to revise the product or service, update your media message or even provide some new offers. Hope this info helps.

I think another element to consider in parallel to a new product launch is what you are changing in your strategy and your startup. Here are a few more ways to look at a new product launch:  A funding opportunity – you’ve launched one product and even if it didn’t go well, you have a pretty strong idea of why that was and you are ready to improve. Plus, even an iota of a product on the market will put you on any angel’s map.Opportunity to revisit productivity – startups need to transfer from ramen-fueled, github factories to sleek, united and productive teams  with clear responsibilities and expectations. This can come from implementing a few tools to assist workflow, implementing a few checklists to follow as you code, putting emphasis on different areas of the business (such as finances, growth and marketing), etc…Building your team – your cofounders kick ass but think about the unique insight, decision making and product iterations you all brought to the table – you need more of that – and fresh! Plus, when you’ve launched your product there’ll be a host of new opportunities now clear to you. Potential hires will see that you are serious and will be attracted to contribute to your amazing company. They’ll be anticipating 2.0 as much as you – don’t waste this opportunity to bring amazing talent to your business.Create better communications mediums with your customers – once you know how they use your product, get better at finding out why and how. Improve your metrics and active communication channels. Could be as simple as implementing User Intelligence and Customer Communication | Intercom or google analytics – whatever the case, see if you can build good communication with your customers into your 2.0 experience. It can only help.Professionalize your finances – ….and documentation. Seriously, most companies forget about managing their finances and documents until they have either a.) run out of money or b.) been approached by an eager VC only to find that they haven’t done any of this. Don’t screw around with your finances and documentation. Get it done early.Implement new technologies – in the months you spent hiding from the world building your product – the world did keep spinning and dozens, if not hundreds of new technologies – potentially relevant to your product – were announced and released. It could be a simple improvement to your technology stack or a revolutionary, telepathic communication system. Whatever the case, if you are going to change your product – you may as well keep it up to date with the latest and best practice in tech. This is often the edge startups have – agility to adopt new technologies – i’d be hesitant to lose it.Hope this proves useful to you and your business!
